description: From Middle English speken (“to speak”), from Old English specan (“to speak”). This is usually taken to be an irregular alteration of earlier sprecan (“to speak”), from Proto-West Germanic *sprekan, from Proto-Germanic *sprekaną (“to speak, make a sound”), from Proto-Indo-European *spreg- (“to make a sound, utter, speak”). Finding this proposed loss of r from the stable cluster spr unparalleled, Hill instead sets up a different root, Proto-West Germanic *spekan (“to negotiate”) from Proto-Indo-European *bʰégʾ-e- (“to distribute”) with *s-mobile, which collapsed in meaning with *sprekan ("to speak" < "to crackle, prattle") and so came to be seen as a free variant thereof.

entries.meaning: language, jargon, or terminology used uniquely in a particular environment or group.
(dated) a low class bar, a speakeasy.

verbs.description: speak (third-person singular simple present speaks, present participle speaking, simple past spoke or (archaic) spake, past participle spoken or (colloquial, nonstandard) spoke)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To communicate with one's voice, to say words out loud.
examples: I was so surprised I couldn't speak.
It's been ages since we've spoken.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To communicate or converse by some means other than orally, such as writing or facial expressions.
examples: He spoke of it in his diary.
Speak to me only with your eyes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deliver a message to a group; to deliver a speech.
examples: This evening I shall speak on the topic of correct English usage.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, stative) To be able to communicate in a language.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To be able to communicate in the manner of specialists in a field.

examples: I was so surprised that I couldn't speak a word.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To communicate (some fact or feeling); to bespeak, to indicate.
examples: Their behaviour to each other speaks the most cordial confidence and happiness.

entries.meaning: (informal, transitive, sometimes humorous) To understand (as though it were a language).
examples: So you can program in C. But do you speak C++?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce a sound; to sound.
Of a bird, to be able to vocally reproduce words or phrases from a human language.
(transitive, archaic) To address; to accost; to speak to.
examples: Spoke the ship Union of Newport, without any anchor. The next day ran down to Acra, where the windlass was again capsized and the pawls broken.
